nodes.text: The inverse-S probability weighting observed in experiments can be explained mechanistically as a difference between the decision maker's and the disinterested observer's probabilistic models, specifically when the decision maker assumes greater uncertainty (larger scale and/or different location/shape) or accounts for estimation uncertainty from finite time series

Probability weighting is the empirical observation that decision weights w(x) inferred from observed choices exceed stated probabilities p(x) for rare events and are lower for common events, producing an inverse-S curve when plotting cumulative decision weights Fw against cumulative probabilities Fp

If a decision maker (DM) models an observable with the same location but larger scale than the disinterested observer (DO), then the DM's PDF w(x) relative to the DO's p(x) follows a power-law relation that places w above p for low densities and below p for high densities, producing an inverse-S in CDF space

When DM and DO differ in both location and scale (or shape), Gaussian and t-distribution examples show that the inverse-S mapping between Fw and Fp persists and can closely reproduce empirically fitted phenomenological functions

If the DM estimates probabilities from finite time series, sampling uncertainty yields relative errors that are larger for rarer events; a DM who conservatively adds standard error to estimated densities and normalises will produce decision weights w(x) that overweight rare events and underweight common events
Tversky and Kahneman's empirical inverse-S curve (decision weights vs stated probabilities) is the canonical observed phenomenon motivating mechanistic explanations

Analytic derivation for Gaussian case: with DO variance sigma^2 and DM variance (alpha sigma)^2, eliminating (x-mu)^2 gives w(p)=p^{1/alpha^2} times a normalization factor, so for alpha>1 exponent<1 and w>p at low p
CDF plots for Gaussian examples show DM CDF Fw above DO CDF Fp at low x and below at high x, yielding the inverse-S when Fw is plotted vs Fp

Fitted two-parameter Gaussian and t-distribution models (fitting location and scale/shape) match experimental data from Tversky and Kahneman (1992) and Tversky and Fox (1995) as well as standard phenomenological functions, indicating mechanistic plausibility

Scaling argument for finite-sample estimation: observed count n(x) ~ p(x) delta x T with standard error sqrt(n(x)), so estimated density p_hat has absolute error ~ sqrt(p_hat/(T delta x)) and relative error ~ 1/sqrt(p_hat T delta x), which increases as p_hat decreases

Simulation and analytic application of the conservative correction p_hat + standard error, followed by normalization, produces inverse-S curves for both Gaussian and fat-tailed t-distributions, with stronger effects for fat tails

Phenomenological fit used in prospect theory (Tversky and Kahneman function with parameter gamma) lacks mechanistic motivation and can introduce artefacts like shifting intersection; mechanistic Gaussian/t models provide physically interpretable alternative fits

Conclusion: the inverse-S should be interpreted as a neutral indicator of differing models or uncertainties between DO and DM rather than necessarily as a cognitive bias of the decision maker; DMs' additional uncertainty and time-perspective (ergodicity considerations) provide principled reasons for cautious overweighting of rare events

Contextual argument: DO and DM have different objectives and information â€” DO often considers ensemble averages while DM faces time evolution and non-ergodic processes (e.g., multiplicative wealth growth), which rationalizes hedging against rare adverse events
Limitation: model assumes DM's conservative correction is adding one standard error and normalising; real DMs may use different conservative rules and other cognitive factors may also play a role
